case_name: Commissioner of Wealth Tax v. M/s. Standard Vacuum Oil Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 627 to 628 of 1964 were filed in Civil Appellate Jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 627 to 628 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated May 14, 1962 of the Calcutta High Court in Wealth Tax Matter No. 154 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated May 14, 1962 of the Calcutta High Court in Wealth Tax Matter No. 154 of 1960.

facts.text: Two questions were referred to the High Court by the Appellate Tribunal under s. 27 of the Wealth Tax Act XXVII of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Two questions were referred to the High Court by the Appellate Tribunal under s. 27 of the Wealth Tax Act XXVII of 1957 .

facts.text: The respondent is M/s. Standard Vacuum Oil Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: respondent company- pany, M s. Standard Vacuum Oil Co. Ltd.,

facts.text: Demands for tax under s. 18A of the Indian Income Tax Act were made against the respondent company for the two years ending December 31, 1956 and December 31, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Demands in respect of the payment of tax under s. 18A of the Indian Income Tax Act were made against the respondent company- pany, M s. Standard Vacuum Oil Co. Ltd., for the two years ending December 31, 1956 and December 31, 1957,

facts.text: Notices of demand dated May 28, 1956 and May 31, 1957 were issued respectively for the two years.

anchor.surface_text: by numberices of demand dated May 28, 1956 and May 31, 1957, respectively.

facts.text: The final instalment of Rs. 47,69,653 for each of the two years was outstanding on the respective valuation dates.

anchor.surface_text: The final instalment of the amount of Rs. 47,69,653 for each of the two years was outstanding on the respective valuation daters.

facts.text: The assessee claimed that the demand for such tax should be allowed as deduction in determining the net wealth under the Wealth Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee claimed that the demand for such, tax should be allowed as deduction in determining the net wealth of the assessee under the Wealth Tax Act.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal held that the sum should be deducted if outstanding for less than a year.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal held that this sum should be deducted from the total companyputation of wealth if the said amount was outstanding for less than a year.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal held that the demand under s. 18A of the Income Tax Act was a debt owed by the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: It further held that the demand created under s. 18A of the Income Tax Act was a debt owed by the assessee,

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal directed the Wealth Tax Officer to ascertain if the demand was outstanding for less than one year on the valuation date and allow deduction if so.

anchor.surface_text: and it directed, the Wealth Tax Officer to ascertain whether the demand referred to in this case was outstanding for less than one year on the valuation date and if so, he will allow the same as a deduction.

facts.text: High Court answered the question in favour of the assessee following Assam Oil Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Wealth Tax.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, following its decision in Assam Oil Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Wealth Tax  Central , Calcutta 1 , answered the question in favour of the assessee.

facts.text: Revenue obtained certificates of fitness from the High Court and filed these appeals in this Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Revenue having obtained certificates of fitness from the High Court filed these appeals in this Court.

facts.text: The second question referred is whether arrears of tax under Section 18A IT Act constitute a debt owed by the assessee within section 2(m) of Wealth Tax Act on valuation date.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, in companyputing the net wealth of the assessee, the arrears of tax as determined as per numberice under Section 18A of the Indian Income Tax Act for the two assessment years under companysideration companystitute a debt owed by the assessee within the meaning of section 2 m  of the Wealth Tax Act as on the valuation date

facts.text: Notices of demand issued under s. 18A(1) of Income Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Now the numberices of demand were issued under s. 18A 1  of the Income Tax Act.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by Sikri, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Sikri, J.

facts.text: Counsel for appellant: V. Viswanatha Sastri, N. D. Karkhanis, R. H. Dhebar and N. Sachthey.

anchor.surface_text: V. Viswanatha Sastri, N. D. Karkhanis, R. H. Dhebar and N. Sachthey, for the appellant.

facts.text: Counsel for respondent: A. Ramachandran, J. B. Dadachanji, O. C. Mathur and Ravinder Narain.

anchor.surface_text: A. Ramachandran, J. B. Dadachanji, O. C. Mathur and Ravinder Narain, for the respondent.

facts.text: Revenue contends that amount under s. 18A is not an ascertained debt as assessee can estimate and pay less.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Viswanatha Sastri, learned companynsel for the Revenue, companytends that on a true interpretation of s. 18A the amount which is payable under it is number an ascertained amount as the assessee can estimate the amount which he should pay as advance tax.

facts.text: Court holds that the High Court was right and the demand under s. 18A is a debt owed within s. 2(m) Wealth Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court was right in answering the question in favour, of the assessee.

arguments.claim: Amounts directed by notices under s.18A(1) are debts owed by assessee within s.2(m) on valuation date

anchor.surface_text: The question with which we are concerned is whether the amounts directed to be paid by notices of demand dated May 28, 1956 and May 31, 1957, are debts owed by the assessee within s. 2 m  on the respective valuation dates.

arguments.claim: s.18A(10) deems assessee in default if not paying demanded instalment, confirming statutory liability

anchor.surface_text: Section 18A 10  provides that if the assessee does not submit a revised estimate under sub-s.  2  of s. 18A, and he does not pay on the specified date any instalment of tax that he is required to pay under sub-s.  1 , he shall be deemed to be an assessee in default

arguments.claim: No substantial difference between s.18A advance tax and tax under demand notice after assessment

anchor.surface_text: We cannot find any substantial difference between advance tax paid under the provisions of s. 18A and tax due and paid under a demand notice passed after an assessment.

arguments.claim: Condition subsequent reducing liability under revised estimate does not convert s.18A liability to contingent

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the observations of the Gujarat High Court in Commissioner of Wealth-Tax v. Raipur Manufacturing Company 1  that a condition subsequent, the fulfilment of which may result in the reduction or even extinction of liability, would not have the effect of converting the liability which attaches under such notice under s. 18A into a contingent liability.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in answering the question in favour of the assessee, i.e., arrears of tax under Section 18A constitute a debt owed by the assessee within section 2(m) of Wealth Tax Act on valuation date

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court was right in answering the question in favour, of the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory demand under s.18A(1) IT Act creates ascertained liability deemed debt under s.2(m) WT Act until assessee submits revised estimate under s.18A(2); s.18A(10) enforces payment by deeming default; analogous to post-assessment demands; not rendered contingent by potential revision

holdings.text: There is no substantial difference between advance tax under s.18A and tax due under demand notice after assessment

anchor.surface_text: We cannot find any substantial difference between advance tax paid under the provisions of s. 18A and tax due and paid under a demand notice passed after an assessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Both create enforceable payment obligations; s.18A allows revision but initial demand is binding until substituted, similar to assessed tax demands

holdings.text: A condition subsequent allowing reduction of liability under s.18A does not convert the liability into a contingent liability

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the observations of the Gujarat High Court in Commissioner of Wealth-Tax v. Raipur Manufacturing Company that a condition subsequent, the fulfilment of which may result in the reduction or even extinction of liability, would not have the effect of converting the liability which attaches under such notice under s. 18A into a contingent liability.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Liability attaches upon notice under s.18A(1); potential revision is condition subsequent, not making it contingent ab initio; follows Gujarat HC precedent

holdings.text: A debt is owed when an order under s.18A(1) is passed and notice of demand is sent; the amount begins to be owed until a new figure is substituted by the assessee

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, a debt is owed when an order under s. 18A 1  is passed and a notice of demand sent. The amount mentioned in the notice begins to be owe till a new figure is substituted by the action of the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.18A(1) order and notice create statutory obligation; persists until assessee acts under s.18A(2); enforced by s.18A(10) deeming default
